dublinCore.dc:title: 113 HR 4065 IH: Smartphone Theft Prevention Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Serrano introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To require mobile service providers and mobile device manufacturers to give consumers the ability to remotely delete data from mobile devices and render such devices inoperable.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Smartphone Theft Prevention Act.

paragraph.text: mobile device theft costs consumers $30,000,000,000 each year, according to the Federal Communications Commission;
1 in 3 robberies include the theft of a mobile device;
consumers deserve to have the most secure technology available to protect them and their information;
the wireless industry should work with law enforcement to educate consumers about the security tools that are available to them and how to keep their data, their devices, and themselves safe; and

because engineering and security needs change rapidly, the mobile device industry, law enforcement, and consumer advocates are best suited to proactively develop solutions to protect consumers, drive innovation, and deter theft.

subsection.text: Part I of title III of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 301 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: the term account holder, with respect to a mobile device—

subparagraph.text: means the person who holds the account through which commercial mobile service or commercial mobile data service is provided on the device; and
includes a person authorized by the person described in subparagraph (A) to take actions with respect to the device;

paragraph.text: the term commercial mobile data service has the meaning given the term in section 6001 of the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 (47 U.S.C. 1401);
the term commercial mobile service has the meaning given the term in section 332; and
the term mobile device means a personal electronic device on which commercial mobile service or commercial mobile data service is provided.
A provider of commercial mobile service or commercial mobile data service on a mobile device shall make available on the device a function that—

subparagraph.text: may only be used by the account holder; and

clause.text: delete or render inaccessible from the device all information relating to the account holder that has been placed on the device;
prevent the device from being reactivated or reprogrammed without a passcode or similar authorization after the device has been—

subclause.text: rendered inoperable as described in clause (ii); or
subject to an unauthorized factory reset; and

clause.text: reverse any action described in clause (i), (ii), or (iii) if the device is recovered by the account holder.

paragraph.text: A person may not manufacture in the United States, or import into the United States for sale or resale to the public, a mobile device unless the device is configured in such a manner that the provider of commercial mobile service or commercial mobile data service on the device may make available on the device the function required under paragraph (1).

subparagraph.text: The Commission may exempt a provider of commercial mobile service or commercial mobile data service on a mobile device from the requirement under paragraph (1), with respect to that device, if the provider makes available on the device technology that accomplishes the functional equivalent of the function required under paragraph (1).

The Commission may exempt a person from the requirement under paragraph (2), with respect to a mobile device that the person manufactures in the United States or imports into the United States for sale or resale to the public, if the device is configured in such a manner that the provider of commercial mobile service or commercial mobile data service on the device may make available on the device technology that accomplishes the functional equivalent of the function required under paragraph (1).

paragraph.header: Waiver for low-cost, voice-only mobile devices
paragraph.text: The Commission may waive the applicability of the requirements under paragraphs (1) and (2) with respect to any low-cost mobile device that—

subparagraph.text: is intended for primarily voice-only mobile service; and
may have limited data consumption functions focused on text messaging or short message service.

subsection.text: A provider of commercial mobile service or commercial mobile data service on a mobile device may not charge the account holder any fee for making the function described in subsection (b)(1), or any equivalent technology described in subsection (b)(3)(A), available to the account holder.

paragraph.text: Any person that is determined by the Commission, in accordance with paragraphs (3) and (4) of section 503(b), to have violated subsection (b) or (c) of this section shall be liable to the United States for a forfeiture penalty, in an amount to be determined by the Commission.
A forfeiture penalty under this subsection shall be in addition to any other penalty provided for in this Act.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit a manufacturer of mobile devices, or a provider of commercial mobile service or commercial mobile data service, from taking actions not described in this section to protect consumers from the theft of mobile devices.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, the term mobile device has the meaning given the term in section 343 of the Communications Act of 1934, as added by subsection (a).
Except as provided in paragraph (3), section 343 of the Communications Act of 1934, as added by subsection (a), shall apply with respect to any mobile device that, on or after January 1, 2015, is—

subparagraph.text: manufactured in the United States; or
imported into the United States for sale to the public.

paragraph.text: The Federal Communications Commission may exempt a person that is subject to any requirement under section 343(b) of the Communications Act of 1934, as added by subsection (a), from that requirement for a temporary period after the date described in paragraph (2) of this subsection, upon a showing by the person that the person requires more time to be able to comply with the requirement.
